Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Investigation of Natural Selection and Host-microbiome-virome Interactions in an Unprecedented and Ongoing Marine Epidemic
Award.AbstractNarration:
Large infectious disease outbreaks allow for relatively faster evolutionary changes in the host, the infectious pathogen, and the community of microorganisms living within the host (the microbiome). While these interactions are poorly understood, they're extremely important in predicting and controlling future outbreaks. The largest recorded marine epidemic ever recorded is currently ongoing in intertidal ecosystems along the west coast of North America. Sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is effecting sea star populations from South Eastern Alaska to Baja California, Mexico and local extinctions are a serious concern. Large-scale epidemics such as these are expected to become more common as the global environment and species' population distributions change. This current disease event provides a unique opportunity to better understand how hosts, the hosts' microbiome, and the disease causing pathogen change throughout an epidemic. The research proposed here will lead to a deeper understanding of these disease events from an evolutionary and ecological perspective by characterizing changes in host and pathogen due to natural selection following epidemics.

This project aims to understand the impact of the microbiome and virome on host disease status and progression at the individual, population, and community levels. The work will contribute to the understanding of an organism as a sum of its inhabitants and will dissect the role of the microbial community in physiological and evolutionary responses to disease. Disease may often be due to a disruption in the balance of an organisms' complex community of microorganisms. Thus, the evolution of disease is not the coevolution of two players (host and pathogen), but rather the coevolution of all members of the host's community. The ongoing Sea Star Wasting Disease event provides a unique opportunity to investigate how this evolution plays out in a widespread epidemic. Specifically, the proposed research aims to (1) identify the targets of natural selection in host and virus populations and (2) investigate molecular mechanisms in the host, virus, and microbiome that underline resistance in hosts and virulence in virus in order to identify the tipping point between asymptomatic and symptomatic hosts. This will be accomplished using a novel sequencing technique that simultaneously collects sequence data from the transcripts of the eukaryotic host, bacterial community, and viral community. This approach allows for identification of the major players in the interaction as well as their functional roles. The understanding of this complicated coevolution will impact the fields of disease ecology and evolution as well as affect the way wildlife and human diseases are understood and, hopefully, prevented or controlled.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this research was to develop a deeper understanding of Sea Star Wasting Disease from microbial and evolutionary perspectives. Specifically, we aimed to characterize the role of the microbiome, the sea star's physiology, and the potential interactions of the microbiome and host physiology in sickness and in health. We performed unique, non-lethal time course sampling studies of sea stars maintained in individual aquaria in the lab. The study directly explored, for the first time, differences in the microbial communities between healthy and sick sea stars through the onset and progression of Sea Star Wasting Disease. We identified putatively beneficial bacteria as well as taxa that shape the tipping point between disease and health. We found results that were simultaneously surprising, but not unexpected, given our new knowledge on the role of microbes in human health. We found that sea stars that could remain healthy had an active microbial community composed of known beneficial and previously uncharacterized microbes. Meanwhile, sea stars that became sick and wasted showed a reduction of these beneficial microbes when symptoms first appeared. Wasting sea stars also showed signs of a suppressed immune system with lower expression of immune related genes than healthy stars. These results support a novel hypothesis, that the microbial community of an individual affects susceptibility to Sea Star Wasting.

This work has been and will continue to be disseminated to the broader public, local, and scientific communities. With the publication of our first study from this work, we did a press release that resulted in coverage in several different local (WCAX), national (Monterey Herald), and international (DW Science, Quartz) media outlets. This coverage has resulted in several visits from K-12 students from across the state of Vermont to my lab to meet with me, learn more about sea star wasting, the health of our oceans, and what they can do to help. I have also organized several tours of my lab for low-income, first-generations students from local community colleges to discuss research and careers in science.

This research has also been shared with diverse stakeholders - resource managers, local, state and federal resource managers, non-profit organizations, and scientists - at the Marine Disease Workshop in October 2018 held in Portland, Oregon. This work has been presented at seven invited and three contributed seminars and has several more publications forthcoming.

Sample cataloguing and sharing with other investigators: The field collections and lab experiments supported by this work have generated a vast library of frozen samples for many of which we have performed DNA and RNA extractions. These samples are available for our future use and for sharing with other investigators studying Sea Star Wasting. The samples include biopsy tissue and water samples taken throughout time course lab experiments investigating sea star wasting disease progression for the ochre sea star (Pisaster ochraceus) lab experiment and field collected biopsy tissue samples from two species, the ochre sea star (Pisaster ochraceus) and the sunflower star (Pycnopodia helianthoides) from areas in Southeast Alaska where sea star wasting disease was and was not present. DNA and RNA have been extracted from these samples and catalogued for future assays. Samples have already served as a resource for other investigators. 

Postdoc and student training and professional development: This grant supported the research and training of one postdoc, one undergraduate Honors College student, and has been used to teach computational approaches for microbiome and RNA-sequencing research in my graduate course, Ecological Genomics.
